title: 107_hr3451
content:
The "Student Success Act of 2001" authorizes individuals to enter into contracts for funding postsecondary education by paying a percentage of future earned income. These human capital investment contracts are valid and enforceable, preempting any state laws restricting assignments of future wages. Terms and conditions of these contracts are outlined in section 102. The "Student Success Act of 2001" allows for human capital investment contracts where eligible students sell percentages of future income to fund education expenses and income taxes. The contracts must specify the percentages of future earned income and comply with certain conditions outlined in the legislation. The investment contract for eligible students must specify the percentages of future earned income to be paid, with maximum amounts for each year and potential adjustments based on income levels. No student can enter into a human capital investment contract if it exceeds the aggregate limitation on obligation. The human capital investment contract sets a limit on the total percentage of a student's future earned income that can be paid under all contracts, not exceeding 20%. The contract specifies the maximum period for payment, not exceeding 180 months, with possible extensions for deferrals. The human capital investment contract allows for a deferral of payments under certain conditions, such as under-employment or unemployment. Repayment does not begin until the student stops attending an eligible institution or no longer meets deferral requirements. The human capital investment contract allows for deferral of payments during periods of unemployment or underemployment. Repayment starts when the student stops attending an eligible institution or no longer meets deferral requirements. A human capital investment contract allows for deferral of payments during periods of unemployment or underemployment, with a maximum deferral period of 48 months. The contract also specifies terms for early repayment based on the remaining term of the payment period. Additionally, before entering into the agreement, the student must be provided with a disclosure document stating that the agreement is not a debt instrument. The human capital investment contract allows for payment deferral during unemployment or underemployment for up to 48 months. The agreement states that the student's payment amount may vary based on future income and cannot be discharged through bankruptcy. Accelerated payments can extinguish the student's obligations under the agreement. SEC. 103. DEFINITIONS. In this title, "earned income" includes compensation and self-employment income. "Compensation" refers to salaries, wages, and other earnings as an employee, excluding deferred compensation or payments to retirement plans. "Self-employment income" is the net earnings from self-employment as defined by the Internal Revenue Code. An "eligible student" is a citizen or national of the United States. An eligible student must be a citizen or national of the United States, a permanent resident, or a resident of specific territories. They must also be enrolled in a program leading to a recognized educational credential at an eligible institution of higher education. An eligible student must be enrolled in a program at an eligible institution of higher education, as defined by the Higher Education Act of 1965. Full-time employment is considered as 35 hours or more per week, totaling 1,820 hours per year. Periods of no employment are calculated separately for each calendar year. The term "State law" refers to any law, decision, rule, regulation, or other action with the effect of a law of any State or political subdivision, including the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, District of Columbia, Guam, and American Samoa. The term "State law" includes laws from the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, the government of the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands. Tax treatment of human capital investment contracts under Title II. Tax treatment of human capital investment contracts under Title II includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Human capital investment contracts are not considered debt instruments and amounts received by students under these contracts are taxable. Additionally, depreciation deductions related to human capital investment contracts are addressed in the amendments. The amendment allows for deductions on human capital investment contracts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction is computed using the straight-line method over a useful life of 15 years or the student's payment period. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section for deductions on human capital investment contracts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow deductions for payments made under human capital investment contracts. Payments under human capital investment contracts are now considered qualifying income for publicly traded partnerships, as per the amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This change is effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. TITLE III--SECURITIES LAW TREATMENT OF HUMAN CAPITAL INVESTMENT CONTRACTS

SEC. 301. POOLING OF HUMAN CAPITAL INVESTMENT CONTRACTS INTO INVESTMENT COMPANIES.

Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 to include human capital investment contracts in the definition of qualifying investments.

TITLE IV--BANKRUPTCY LAW TREATMENT OF HUMAN CAPITAL INVESTMENT CONTRACTS.

SEC. 401. EXCEPTION TO DISCHARGE. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include a provision regarding payments owed by the debtor under a human capital investment contract, with exceptions for debts due more than 7 years prior to filing for bankruptcy or if discharging the debt would cause undue hardship on the debtor. The paragraph states that discharging a debt under a human capital investment contract may cause undue hardship on the debtor and their dependents. The amendment to the Higher Education Act of 1965 exempts amounts received from human capital investment contracts from being considered as income in the calculation of financial need for education programs.
